gallery_slide.gallery_image_caption: After a long day harvesting cucumbers and tomatoes for a Walmart supplier, Lucio Marquez Garcia (seated) and his 10-year-old son eat a dinner of vegetables they scrounged near their labor camp. The family dines at a handmade table between concrete bunks in their 12x12-foot room, one of 20 rooms in the tin-walled building.

Alejandrina Castillo, 12, and her brother Fidel, 14, take a 14-hour journey across Mexico in a pickup truck crammed with all their worldly possessions. Barletti tracked the family for a year, following them from one farm to another.

December 4, 2013. Teacapan, Sinaloa, Mexico. Alejandrina Castillo, 12, and her 11-yr-old cousin Jesus Vasquez watch television through a neighbor's window across the dirt street from their rented house in Teacapan, Mexico. She has trouble finding friends due to her nomadic lifestyle. "If I had a friend from here before, when I come back she will be mad at me because I left.  So it's better not to have any friends."

December 4, 2013. Teacapan, Sinaloa, Mexico. Alejandrina Castillo, age 12, picks chile peppers in a field in Teacapan, Sinaloa, Mexico. She wears a bracelet given by a third grade classmate whom she hasn't seen in 3 years. Her nomadic, migratory life keeps her out of school and away from home all year. Ale said, "I work because we need money to eat things."

December 10, 2013. Guasave, Sinaloa, Mexico. Behind the high fence that surrounds Campo Sacramento in Guasave, Sinaloa, 7-yr-old Udiel Castro plays with a kite he fashioned from a plastic grocery bag. Many people like this youngster's family who work in Mexico's export agriculture industry are indigenous people from some of the poorest parts of the country.
